narrative.title: NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan
narrative.project_title: NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan: Clinical and MRI Data from Human Research Participants

question.text: Types and amount of scientific data expected to be generated in the project

json.answer: The project titled 'NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan: Clinical and MRI Data from Human Research Participants' expects to generate a significant amount of scientific data, including demographic, clinical, and MRI-based imaging data. Specifically, the dataset will comprise participant-level clinical/demographic tables for 220 participants (110 affected youth and 110 matched healthy controls) and multi-modal MRI imaging data (structural MRI, fMRI, and 1H fMRS). The total volume of data will depend on the imaging protocols used and the derivatives retained, with imaging data expected to be the largest component.

question.text: Scientific data that will be preserved and shared, and the rationale for doing so

json.answer: All collected data, including demographic, clinical, and MRI-based imaging data, along with derived imaging measures/features and supporting documentation (data dictionaries, protocols, README), will be preserved and shared. The rationale for sharing these data is to facilitate transparency, reproducibility, and further research in the field by providing a comprehensive dataset that can be used by other researchers to explore new hypotheses or validate existing findings.

question.text: Metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation

json.answer:
To facilitate interpretation of the scientific data, the following metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation will be made accessible:
- Data dictionaries for clinical and demographic data
- Protocols for MRI data acquisition
- README files explaining the structure and content of the shared datasets
- Study instruments used for data collection
These materials will provide context and enable other researchers to understand and appropriately use the shared data.

section.title: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

question.text: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

json.answer:
Specialized tools and software are needed to access or manipulate some of the shared scientific data, particularly the MRI imaging data. Required tools include:
- MRI analysis software such as FSL (FMRIB Software Library) or AFNI (Analysis of Functional NeuroImages)
- Statistical software like R or Python libraries for data manipulation and analysis
These tools can be accessed through their respective websites or repositories, and instructions on how to use them will be provided in the shared documentation.

To enable interoperability of datasets and resources, common data standards will be applied to the scientific data and associated metadata. Specifically:
- The Brain Imaging Data Structure (BIDS) standard will be used for organizing and describing MRI imaging data
- For demographic and clinical data, standards from the National Institutes of Health (NIH) Common Data Elements (CDE) initiative will be applied where applicable
These standards will facilitate the integration of our dataset with other datasets and promote collaborative research.

section.title: Element 4: Data Preservation, Access, and Associated Timelines

question.text: Repository where scientific data and metadata will be archived

json.answer: The scientific data and metadata arising from this project will be archived in the NIMH Data Archive (NDA). The NDA is a repository that supports the sharing and reuse of data related to mental health research, making it an appropriate choice for our study.

question.text: How scientific data will be findable and identifiable

json.answer: To ensure that the scientific data are findable and identifiable, each dataset will be assigned a persistent unique identifier (DOI) upon publication in the NDA. This DOI will allow other researchers to easily locate and access our datasets.

question.text: When and how long the scientific data will be made available

json.answer: The scientific data will be made available no later than the time of an associated publication or end of the performance period, whichever comes first. Once archived, the data will remain accessible for at least 10 years following the end of the project to allow for long-term research and validation studies.

section.title: Element 5: Access, Distribution, or Reuse Considerations

question.text: Factors affecting subsequent access, distribution, or reuse of scientific data

json.answer: While we aim to maximize data sharing, factors such as informed consent limitations and privacy protections may affect subsequent access, distribution, or reuse. Since all participants will provide broad consent for data sharing, these limitations are expected to be minimal. However, any identifiable information will be removed from the shared datasets to protect participant confidentiality.

question.text: Whether access to scientific data will be controlled

json.answer: Access to the scientific data will not be controlled beyond the standard access controls implemented by the NDA for managing and distributing sensitive human subjects data. The data will be available upon request, following approval through the NDA's Data Access Request process.

question.text: Protections for privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants

json.answer: To protect the privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants, all shared datasets will be deidentified prior to submission to the NDA. Additionally, a Certificate of Confidentiality will be obtained from the NIH to further safeguard against disclosure of identifiable information.

section.title: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

question.text: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

json.answer: Compliance with this Data Management and Sharing Plan will be monitored and managed by the project's Principal Investigator (PI) in collaboration with the institutional data management office. Regular reviews (at least biannually) will ensure that all data are properly documented, stored, and shared according to the plan outlined here and any relevant regulatory requirements. The PI and designated personnel will oversee data sharing requests and ensure that access is granted in accordance with the terms of consent and applicable laws and regulations.
